segment.target: Plan your DirectX port

segment.source: Plan your game porting project from DirectX 9 to DirectX 11 and Universal Windows Platform (UWP)-- upgrade your graphics code, and put your game in the Windows Runtime environment.
segment.target: Plan your game porting project from DirectX 9 to DirectX 11 and Universal Windows Platform (UWP)-- upgrade your graphics code, and put your game in the Windows Runtime environment.

segment.target: Plan your DirectX port

segment.source: Summary
segment.target: Summary

segment.source: Plan your DirectX port
segment.target: Plan your DirectX port

segment.source: Important changes from Direct3D 9 to Direct3D 11
segment.target: Important changes from Direct3D 9 to Direct3D 11

segment.source: Feature mapping
segment.target: Feature mapping

segment.source: Plan your game porting project from DirectX 9 to DirectX 11 and Universal Windows Platform (UWP): upgrade your graphics code, and put your game in the Windows Runtime environment.
segment.target: Plan your game porting project from DirectX 9 to DirectX 11 and Universal Windows Platform (UWP): upgrade your graphics code, and put your game in the Windows Runtime environment.

segment.source: Plan to port graphics code
segment.target: Plan to port graphics code

segment.source: Before you begin porting your game to UWP, it's important to ensure that your game does not have any holdovers from Direct3D 8.
segment.target: Before you begin porting your game to UWP, it's important to ensure that your game does not have any holdovers from Direct3D 8.

segment.source: Ensure that your game doesn't have any remnants of the fixed function pipeline.
segment.target: Ensure that your game doesn't have any remnants of the fixed function pipeline.

segment.source: For a complete list of deprecated features, including fixed pipeline functionality, see Deprecated Features.
segment.target: For a complete list of deprecated features, including fixed pipeline functionality, see Deprecated Features.

segment.source: Upgrading from Direct3D 9 to Direct3D 11 is more than a search-and-replace change.
segment.target: Upgrading from Direct3D 9 to Direct3D 11 is more than a search-and-replace change.

segment.source: You need to know the difference between the Direct3D device, device context, and graphics infrastructure, and learn about other important changes since Direct3D 9.
segment.target: You need to know the difference between the Direct3D device, device context, and graphics infrastructure, and learn about other important changes since Direct3D 9.

segment.source: You can start this process by reading the other topics in this section.
segment.target: You can start this process by reading the other topics in this section.

segment.source: You must replace the D3DX and DXUT helper libraries with your own helper libraries, or with community tools.
segment.target: You must replace the D3DX and DXUT helper libraries with your own helper libraries, or with community tools.

segment.source: See the Feature mapping section for more info.
segment.target: See the Feature mapping section for more info.

segment.source: Note You can use the DirectX Tool Kit or DirectXTex to replace some functionality that was formerly provided by D3DX and DXUT.
segment.target: Note You can use the DirectX Tool Kit or DirectXTex to replace some functionality that was formerly provided by D3DX and DXUT.

segment.source: Shaders written in assembly language should be upgraded to HLSL using shader model 4 level 9\_1 or 9\_3 functionality, and shaders written for the Effects library will need to be updated to a more recent version of HLSL syntax.
segment.target: Shaders written in assembly language should be upgraded to HLSL using shader model 4 level 9\_1 or 9\_3 functionality, and shaders written for the Effects library will need to be updated to a more recent version of HLSL syntax.

segment.source: See the Feature mapping section for more info.
segment.target: See the Feature mapping section for more info.

segment.source: Get familiar with the different Direct3D feature levels.
segment.target: Get familiar with the different Direct3D feature levels.

segment.source: Feature levels classify a wide range of video hardware by defining sets of known functionality.
segment.target: Feature levels classify a wide range of video hardware by defining sets of known functionality.

segment.source: Each set roughly corresponds to versions of Direct3D, from 9.1 through 11.2.
segment.target: Each set roughly corresponds to versions of Direct3D, from 9.1 through 11.2.

segment.source: All feature levels use the DirectX 11 API.
segment.target: All feature levels use the DirectX 11 API.

segment.source: Plan to port Win32 UI code to CoreWindow
segment.target: Plan to port Win32 UI code to CoreWindow

segment.source: UWP apps run in a window created for an app container, called a CoreWindow.
segment.target: UWP apps run in a window created for an app container, called a CoreWindow.

segment.source: Your game controls the window by inheriting from IFrameworkView, which requires less implementation details than a desktop window.
segment.target: Your game controls the window by inheriting from IFrameworkView, which requires less implementation details than a desktop window.

segment.source: Your game's main loop will be in the IFrameworkView::Run method.
segment.target: Your game's main loop will be in the IFrameworkView::Run method.

segment.source: The lifecycle of a UWP app is very different from a desktop app.
segment.target: The lifecycle of a UWP app is very different from a desktop app.

segment.source: You'll need to save the game often, because when a suspend event happens your app only has a limited amount of time to stop running code, and you want to make sure the player can get back to where they were right away when your app resumes.
segment.target: You'll need to save the game often, because when a suspend event happens your app only has a limited amount of time to stop running code, and you want to make sure the player can get back to where they were right away when your app resumes.

segment.source: Games should save just often enough to maintain a continuous gameplay experience from resume, but not so often that the game saves impact framerate or cause the game to stutter.
segment.target: Games should save just often enough to maintain a continuous gameplay experience from resume, but not so often that the game saves impact framerate or cause the game to stutter.

segment.source: Your game will potentially need to load game state when the game resumes from a terminated state.
segment.target: Your game will potentially need to load game state when the game resumes from a terminated state.

segment.source: DirectXMath can be used as a replacement for D3DXMath and XNAMath, and it can come in handy if you need a math library.
segment.target: DirectXMath can be used as a replacement for D3DXMath and XNAMath, and it can come in handy if you need a math library.

segment.source: DirectXMath has fast, portable data types, and types that are aligned and packed for use with shaders.
segment.target: DirectXMath has fast, portable data types, and types that are aligned and packed for use with shaders.

segment.source: Native libraries such as the Interlocked API have been expanded to support ARM intrinsics.
segment.target: Native libraries such as the Interlocked API have been expanded to support ARM intrinsics.

segment.source: If your game uses interlocked APIs, you can keep using them in DirectX 11 and UWP.
segment.target: If your game uses interlocked APIs, you can keep using them in DirectX 11 and UWP.

segment.source: Our templates and code samples use new C++ features that you might not be familiar with yet.
segment.target: Our templates and code samples use new C++ features that you might not be familiar with yet.

segment.source: For example, asynchronous methods are used with lambda expressions to load Direct3D resources without blocking the UI thread.
segment.target: For example, asynchronous methods are used with lambda expressions to load Direct3D resources without blocking the UI thread.

segment.source: There are two concepts you'll use often:
segment.target: There are two concepts you'll use often:

segment.source: Managed references ([]https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/yk97tc08.aspx) and managed classes (ref classes) are a fundamental part of the Windows Runtime.
segment.target: Managed references ([]https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/yk97tc08.aspx) and managed classes (ref classes) are a fundamental part of the Windows Runtime.

segment.source: You will need to use managed ref classes to interface with Windows Runtime components, for example IFrameworkView (more on that in the walkthrough).
segment.target: You will need to use managed ref classes to interface with Windows Runtime components, for example IFrameworkView (more on that in the walkthrough).

segment.source: When working with Direct3D 11 COM interfaces, use the Microsoft::WRL::ComPtr template type to make COM pointers easier to use.
segment.target: When working with Direct3D 11 COM interfaces, use the Microsoft::WRL::ComPtr template type to make COM pointers easier to use.
